Sequence Information.Peptide Name: TCP (Thrombin-derived C-terminal Peptide, natural AMPs; humans; primates, mammals, animals; BBL; Derivatives: VFR17 and HVF18)

Literature Information.Literature: AMP Significance: A recent study reveals the significance of TCP in host defense.  TCP binds to LPS or E. coli, leading to bacterial permeation and amyloidation/aggregation/agglutination (bacteria-agglutinating)?, which promotea clearance by phagocytic uptake (Petrlova et al., 2017).Discovery: Detected in human wounds in vivo.Activity: Radial diffusion assay: active against E. coli ATCC 25922 and P. aeruginosa ATCC 27852.SAR:  synthetic shorter peptides from the very C-terminus of TCP are antibacterial and adopt helical conformation in lipid environments. The peptides inhibit macrophage responses to bacterial LPS by binding to LPS. Protect mice sepsis. These results establish a link between the coagulation system and host defense peptides.Toxicity: Unlike the fragment GKY-25, rTCP96 was not hemolytic at 10 uM.Recombinant production:bacteria:Escherichia coli: BL21 expression system has been established. Similar to the isolated form, the recombinant form rTCP96 can kill E. coli.Updated 5/2017; 2/2023.
Literature Information.Author: Papareddy P, Rydengård V, Pasupuleti M, Walse B, Mörgelin M, Chalupka A, Malmsten M, Schmidtchen A.2010
Literature Information.Title: Proteolysis of human thrombin generates novel host defense peptides
